newsitem.title: USA: Silicon Valley firm puts "Push" to corporate use.
newsitem.headline: Silicon Valley firm puts "Push" to corporate use.

text.p: A crowd of companies is trying to use so-called "push" technology to win consumers' attention on a crowded World Wide Web -- but one firm is marketing the technology for a behind-the-scenes business product.

"Push," the latest fine-tuning of Internet technology, is a method of distributing information over the Internet so that it goes automatically to people who have essentially subscribed to it. It's often marketed as a device that eliminates the tedium of searching for information.

Quintus Corp., a Fremont, Calif.-based maker of customer service software, has introduced software joining push technology and so-called intranets for customer service applications. Intranets are private, internal corporate computer networks that operate like the Internet.

Its "ImpaQ" software is designed to let key employees in a company get real-time information about customers "pushed" to them at vital moments from in-house databases or from partners' databases over intranets.
Using the information, a sales representative might, for example, prevent a customer defection by resolving the problem of a missed shipment before the customer calls to complain.
CUSTOMER SERVICE WILL BE CRUCIAL

"Customer service is at the core of most (companies') challenges," Quintus President Alan Anderson said in an interview. "In the future, the only thing that is going to differentiate a company is its customer service."
Quintus likes to cite a potential use for ImpaQ in the hotel business.

For example, a hotel with an intranet-to-intranet data-sharing arrangement with an airline gets information flashed to it that a registered guest's flight arrived late. The hotel, Anderson said, could respond by being ready for the weary traveller when he or she arrives and prevent a wait in the check-in line and the risk of an angry guest.

"I believe the hospitality industry will subscribe to this fairly aggressively. Customer service is a problem for hotels and airlines that both industries are already spending heavily to fix,' he said.
Hilton Hotels Corp. is a Quintus customer for its other customer service products, Anderson said. He said that when Hilton officials were briefed on the product they "did a back flip."

Another example might be a pharmaceutical firm's sales and shipping departments getting notices "pushed" to them the moment a pharmacy runs out of its product. The pharmaceutical firm would then be able to replenish the stock before the pharmacy has time to ponder switching suppliers.
Privately held Quintus, which sells other customer service and call centre software, competes with many vendors, the largest of which are probably Verity Inc. and Clarify Inc., analysts said.
QUINTUS SAID LEADING IN FAST-GROWING MARKET
But the market is growing fast for all -- about 40 percent a year, the Gartner Group research firm estimates.

Quintus hopes to differentiate itself -- at least temporarily -- as the only customer service software seller to use "push" technology on private intranets, offering real-time pervasive customer information, analysts said. Verity offers an e-mail notification service using the Internet.

"This is a very functionality-driven marketplace. Quintus is the first one to come out with this sort of technology, this functionality, of making customer information pervasively available within an organisation," said Gartner Group analyst Carter Lusher.
"What is unique is it's centred on better information flow for customer management," said META Group analyst Kurt Johnson.
Quintus was the first company to use "push" technology for a purely business-to-business purpose using closed intranets.
The company plans to make the software generally available in the second quarter.
